claim_reports.claim_text: Climate change is due to increasing greenhouse gases from human activity.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim that climate change is due to increasing greenhouse gases from human activity. High-reliability sources, including NASA and the Climate.gov, confirm that human activities, particularly fossil fuel combustion, are significantly raising greenhouse gas concentrations, thereby enhancing the greenhouse effect and driving global warming.

supports.title: Are humans causing or contributing to global warming? - Climate
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that human activities are significantly increasing greenhouse gas concentrations in the atmosphere, which enhances the greenhouse effect and contributes to global warming. It specifically states that the elevated CO2 levels are a direct result of human activities, particularly the burning of fossil fuels.
supports.snippet: Yes, by increasing the abundance of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere, human activities are amplifying Earth's natural greenhouse effect.

supports.title: The Causes of Climate Change - NASA Science
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence clearly supports the claim that climate change is due to increasing greenhouse gases from human activity, detailing how human emissions of CO2, methane, and nitrous oxide have significantly increased since the Industrial Revolution, contributing to global warming.
supports.snippet: Human Activity Is the Cause of Increased Greenhouse Gas Concentrations. Over the last century, burning of fossil fuels like coal and oil has ...

supports.title: What Causes Climate Change? Human and Natural Causes - NRDC
supports.evidence_summary: The article discusses various human activities such as transportation, electricity generation, and agriculture that contribute to the increase of greenhouse gases, which are a primary driver of climate change.
supports.snippet: Human-driven causes of climate change: Transportation, Electricity generation, Industry & manufacturing, Agriculture, Oil & gas development, Buildings, ...

claim_reports.claim_text: The last years have been the warmest since modern record-keeping began.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: Multiple high-reliability sources confirm that the last decade (2015-2024) has seen the warmest years on record, with 2024 being the warmest year since modern record-keeping began in 1850. This strongly supports the claim that recent years have been the warmest.

supports.title: Climate change: global temperature
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that the last decade (2015-2024) has seen the ten warmest years on record, with 2024 being the warmest year since records began in 1850, supporting the claim that recent years have been the warmest since modern record-keeping began.
supports.snippet: The ten warmest years in the 175-year record have all occurred during the last decade (2015–2024).

supports.title: World of Change: Global Temperatures - NASA Science
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that the past nine years have been the warmest years since modern recordkeeping began in 1880, supporting the claim about recent temperature trends.
supports.snippet: The past nine years have been the warmest years since modern recordkeeping began in 1880. As the maps show, global warming does not mean temperatures rise ...

supports.title: WMO confirms 2024 as warmest year on record at about 1.55°C ...
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that 2024 was the warmest year on record since modern record-keeping began in 1850, with global temperatures significantly above historical averages.
supports.snippet: WMO confirms 2024 as warmest year on record at about 1.55°C above pre-industrial level · The past ten years 2015-2024 are the ten warmest years ...

supports.title: Earth's 10 Hottest Years on Record Are the Last 10
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that the last decade has been the warmest on record since modern record-keeping began in 1880, with the past nine years being the warmest years recorded.
supports.snippet: 2024 was the single warmest year on record, surpassing even 2023's wide lead over other recent years.

supports.title: Temperatures Rising: NASA Confirms 2024 Warmest Year on Record
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that 2024 is the warmest year on record since modern record-keeping began in 1880, and that the past decade has been the warmest overall, supporting the claim.
supports.snippet: 2024 was Earth's warmest year since modern record-keeping began around 1880, and the past 10 consecutive years have been the warmest 10 on ...

claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence overwhelmingly supports the claim that the planet's climate is changing, with multiple high-reliability sources confirming that 2023 was the warmest year on record and highlighting significant increases in global temperatures primarily driven by human activity.

supports.title: Monthly Climate Reports | Global Climate Report | Annual 2023
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that 2023 was the warmest year on record, with significant increases in global temperatures and numerous monthly records being set, supporting the claim that the planet's climate is changing.
supports.snippet: The year 2023 had the highest global mean surface temperature in the record, helped by the warm El Niño SST conditions over the last two-thirds of the year.

supports.title: Climate change: global temperature
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that the planet's climate is indeed changing, as global average surface temperatures have risen significantly since the pre-industrial era, with a notable increase in recent decades.
supports.snippet: Earth's temperature has risen by an average of 0.11° Fahrenheit (0.06° Celsius) per decade since 1850, or about 2° F in total.

supports.title: [PDF] CLIMATE CHANGE 2023
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence presented confirms that the planet's climate is changing, highlighting that 2023 was a record warm year and that human activity is the principal cause of the ongoing warming trend since the industrial revolution.
supports.snippet: The evidence is too limited to make a similar robust conclusion for limiting warming to 1.5°C. Limiting global warming to 1.5°C instead of 2°C would increase ...

supports.title: NASA Analysis Confirms 2023 as Warmest Year on Record
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that the planet's climate is changing, as indicated by the record-high global temperatures in 2023 and the acknowledgment of a climate crisis by NASA officials. The analysis highlights the significant warming trend driven by human activity, particularly fossil fuel emissions, and the observable impacts such as extreme heat and rising sea levels.
supports.snippet: Earth's average surface temperature in 2023 was the warmest on record, according to an analysis by NASA. Global temperatures last year were ...

supports.title: Why record 2023 warming matters even if you don't cover climate
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that the planet's climate is changing, as demonstrated by the record warmth of 2023 and the long-term trend of increasing global temperatures primarily caused by human activity. The article cites that 2023 was the hottest year on record and emphasizes the ongoing warming trend since the industrial revolution, attributing it largely to human actions such as burning fossil fuels.
supports.snippet: The research says on why 2023 was a record warm year and how climate predictions affect a range of news beats, from agriculture to aviation.

claim_reports.verdict_summary: Multiple high-reliability sources confirm that sea levels are rising, with satellite and tide gauge data indicating an increase of about 3.3 millimeters per year, accelerating over time. Notably, NASA reports a total rise of approximately 4 inches since 1993, and other studies highlight significant impacts such as coastal erosion and flooding.

supports.title: Can't 'See' Sea Level Rise? You're Looking in the Wrong Place
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that sea levels are indeed rising, with satellite and tide gauge data indicating an increase of about 3.3 millimeters (0.13 inches) per year, which is accelerating over time. This rise contributes to coastal erosion and increased flooding, demonstrating the real impacts of sea level rise.
supports.snippet: “Thanks to satellite and tide gauge data, we know that sea level is rising about 3.3 millimeters (0.13 inches) a year, a rate that grows by ...

supports.title: NASA Analysis Sees Spike in 2023 Global Sea Level Due to El Niño
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that global sea levels are rising, with a reported increase of about 0.3 inches from 2022 to 2023, attributed to climate change and El Niño effects. Additionally, long-term data shows a total rise of approximately 4 inches since 1993, indicating an accelerating trend in sea level rise.
supports.snippet: Global average sea level rose by about 0.3 inches (0.76 centimeters) from 2022 to 2023, a relatively large jump due mostly to a warming climate ...

supports.title: Why is Global Sea Level Rising? - Earth.gov
supports.evidence_summary: The article provides substantial evidence that sea levels are rising, citing data that shows a rise of about 3.3 millimeters per year, with an increase in the rate of rise over time. It discusses the impacts of this rise on coastal erosion and flooding, confirming the claim that sea levels are indeed rising due to climate change.
supports.snippet: Global sea level rise is mainly driven by climate change. Global warming from human activities leads to ocean warming and melting ice sheets and glaciers.

supports.title: Sea level rise: Everything you need to know
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that global sea levels have risen significantly, with a recorded increase of over 10 cm since 1993 and an acceleration in the rate of rise due to climate change effects.
supports.snippet: Global sea levels have already risen by over 10cm between 1993 and 2024, according to NASA, which says sea levels have been rising at ...

supports.title: The rate of global sea level rise doubled during the past three decades
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that global sea levels are indeed rising, with the rate of increase accelerating significantly over the past three decades, from approximately 2.1 mm/year in 1993 to about 4.5 mm/year in 2023.
supports.snippet: The rate of global mean sea level rise over those three decades has increased from ~2.1 mm/year in 1993 to ~4.5 mm/year in 2023.

supports.title: These Photographs Show How the Rising Sea Connects Us All
supports.evidence_summary: The article provides substantial evidence that sea levels are rising, citing data that shows a rise of about 3.3 millimeters per year, with significant contributions from global warming and the melting of ice sheets. It discusses the impacts of this rise, including increased coastal erosion and flooding, confirming the claim.
supports.snippet: The rapid melting of Greenland's ice sheet, the second-largest body of ice on earth after Antarctica, is the main driver of sea level rise ...

claim_reports.claim_text: We're seeing more extreme events like heatwaves and heavy rainfall and wildfire.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: Multiple high-reliability sources, including NASA and NOAA, confirm that climate change is leading to an increase in the frequency and intensity of extreme weather events such as heatwaves, heavy rainfall, and wildfires, strongly supporting the claim.

supports.title: Wildfires and Climate Change - NASA Science
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that climate change is leading to more frequent and intense wildfires, with fire seasons extending beyond traditional periods, which aligns with the claim about increasing extreme weather events.
supports.snippet: Earth's warming climate is amplifying wildland fire activity, particularly in northern and temperate forests.

supports.title: Billion-Dollar Weather and Climate Disasters
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that extreme weather events, including heatwaves, heavy rainfall, and wildfires, are increasing in frequency and intensity due to climate change, which aligns with the claim about the rise of such extreme events.
supports.snippet: The US sustained 403 weather and climate disasters from 1980–2024 where overall damages/costs reached or exceeded $1 billion (including CPI adjustment to 2024).

supports.title: Extreme Weather and Climate Change - NASA Science
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that climate change is increasing the frequency and intensity of extreme weather events, including heatwaves, heavy rainfall, and wildfires, confirming the claim.
supports.snippet: Record-breaking heat waves on land and in the ocean, drenching rains, severe floods, years-long droughts, extreme wildfires, and widespread ...

supports.title: How climate change worsens heatwaves, droughts, fires and floods
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that climate change is indeed causing an increase in the frequency and intensity of extreme weather events, including heatwaves, heavy rainfall, and wildfires. It cites specific instances and scientific assessments that link these phenomena to human-caused warming.
supports.snippet: Rising global temperatures mean extreme weather events are becoming more common and more intense.

claim_reports.claim_text: Scientists at NASA and around the world are researching climate change.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: Multiple high-reliability sources confirm that NASA and other scientists are actively researching climate change, as evidenced by NASA's Earth science initiatives and significant reports like the Fifth National Climate Assessment.

supports.title: Charting the Exceptional, Unexpected Heat of 2023 and 2024
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that NASA is actively involved in researching climate change and its impacts through various Earth science initiatives.
supports.snippet: The charts on this page show how much global temperatures in 2023 and 2024 diverged from expectations based on NASA's temperature record.

supports.title: Scientific Consensus - NASA Science
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that NASA is actively involved in researching climate change and its impacts on the Earth, as part of its Earth Science initiatives.
supports.snippet: According to NASA, Earth's average surface temperature in 2023 was the warmest on record since recordkeeping began in 1880, continuing a long- ...

supports.title: State of the Global Climate 2023
supports.evidence_summary: The article discusses the Fifth National Climate Assessment, which is a significant report on climate change impacts and responses, indicating that research on climate change is ongoing, including efforts by NASA and other scientists.
supports.snippet: The WMO report confirmed that 2023 was the warmest year on record, with the global average near-surface temperature at 1.45 °Celsius.

supports.title: [PDF] CLIMATE CHANGE 2023
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that there is ongoing research and assessment of climate change by various scientific bodies, including NASA and the U.S. Global Change Research Program, as reflected in the Fifth National Climate Assessment.
supports.snippet: This Synthesis Report (SYR) of the IPCC Sixth Assessment Report (AR6) summarises the state of knowledge of climate change, its widespread impacts and risks, and ...

supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that NASA is actively involved in researching climate change and its impacts on the Earth, as part of its Earth Science initiatives.

supports.title: State of Climate Action 2023 | World Resources Institute
supports.evidence_summary: The article discusses the Fifth National Climate Assessment, which is a significant report on climate change impacts and responses, indicating that research on climate change is ongoing, including efforts by U.S. scientists.
supports.snippet: The State of Climate Action 2023 finds that global efforts to limit warming to 1.5°C are failing across the board, with recent progress made on ...

claim_reports.claim_text: We develop computer models to understand future climate change.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim that computer models are developed to understand future climate change. Multiple high-reliability sources, including NASA and NOAA, confirm that climate models simulate various scenarios based on physical principles to predict future climate behavior.

supports.title: Basics of Global Climate Models
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that computer models, specifically climate models, are developed to simulate and understand future climate change by projecting various scenarios based on greenhouse gas levels and other factors.
supports.snippet: Global climate models are computer programs that consist of several hundred thousand lines of code. They calculate the interactions between the ocean, ...

supports.title: Climate Models
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that climate models are developed to improve understanding and predictability of climate behavior, including future climate change, by simulating various climate processes and their interactions.
supports.snippet: Climate models are computer programs that simulate weather patterns over time. By running these simulations, climate models can estimate the Earth's average ...

supports.title: Climate Models | NOAA Climate.gov
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that computer models are developed to simulate and understand future climate change by using mathematical equations to represent physical processes and climate forcing scenarios.
supports.snippet: Climate models are based on well-documented physical processes to simulate the transfer of energy and materials through the climate system.

supports.title: What Are Climate Models? - NASA Science
supports.evidence_summary: The article explains that climate models are essential tools for understanding and predicting future climate change, allowing scientists to simulate various climate scenarios and their impacts. It emphasizes that these models are based on well-founded physical principles and have been validated through historical data, thus supporting the claim that computer models are developed to understand future climate change.
supports.snippet: In a climate model, a scientist can change the temperature of the oceans safely inside a computer. The model then figures how lots of other ...

supports.title: High-resolution climate model forecasts a wet, turbulent future
supports.evidence_summary: The article discusses the development of climate models, including both traditional physics-based models and advanced AI models, to understand and predict future climate changes. It emphasizes the importance of using appropriate modeling techniques to inform climate policy decisions.
supports.snippet: For all their usefulness in forecasting global warming, climate models tend to paint the future in the broad strokes of an Impressionist artist.

transcript_data.text: Why does climate change matter? NASA We Asked a NASA Scientist. Well, it's happening. We look at the Earth from space and we measure it on the ground. And what we see is that the planet's climate is changing. The last years have been the warmest since modern record-keeping began. It's serious. Even a little change in temperature can have big effects. And we're seeing some of those effects now. Sea levels are rising. We're seeing more extreme events like heatwaves and heavy rainfall and wildfire. And we know that a lot of those effects are going to increase with more warming. These changes are impacting decisions that some people make every day, like a farmer thinking about what crops to grow or a homeowner thinking about flood risk. But there's hope. There are scientists at NASA and around the world that are researching this. We know more about our planet than we have ever before, and we learn more every day. So we know why climate is changing. We know that it's due to increasing greenhouse gases from human activity. We also have tools that can help us better understand and better prepare for future climate change. So we develop computer models that help us understand how much it might change in the future. And we're also developing technologies here at NASA and around the world that can help us limit future warming or respond to the warming that we're experiencing. So why does climate change matter? It's real. It's serious, and it's here. We Asked a NASA Scientist. NASA. A NASA 360 Production.
